headline.main: She Waited To Exhale; Now She Can

docs.abstract: Frank Bruni interviews actress Delta Burke, who talks about her journey into obesity, self-acceptance and image adjustment after spending years trying to fit ingenue mold using diet pills and purging; Burke has come to terms with her larger self as have several other actresses, once known as svelte; photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: DELTA BURKE examined the starchy treasure before her, extended two of her perfectly manicured fingers and did something that, for a long and haunted stretch of her past, she would not do in public, at least not without fearing the titters of tabloids and feeling the lash of her own shame. She grabbed hold of a French fry. She dragged it through ketchup. And then, without apology or visible regret, she ate it.
docs.snippet: The actress Delta Burke, who is now starring in "Steel Magnolias" on Broadway, discusses her conflicted relationship with food.

docs.abstract: Dr Lisa Handwerker letter on Jane E Brody's Mar 29 Personal Health column about dual problem with obesity and diabetes describes success of ongoing program in New York City geared to help overweight children eat better (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re the Personal Health column '''Diabesity,' a Crisis in an Expanding Country'' (March 29): The author's concern about the dual epidemic of obesity and diabetes is shared by health professionals who work in New York City's underserved communities, where we see the direct impact on children every day. Last year, the Children's Aid Society began a program in a public school in New York that educates children and their parents about exercise and healthy diets. We also made trips to local bodegas and markets to urge them to stock more fresh produce and healthier food. So far the program has been a success.
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Re the Personal Health column '''Diabesity,' a Crisis in an Expanding Country'' (March 29): The author's concern about the dual epidemic of obesity and diabetes is shared by health professionals who work in New York City's...

headline.main: Sparing the Calories Won't Spoil the Child

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses alarming trend of childhood obesity and describes ways to help children improve overall health and weight; estimated 15 percent of American children ages 6 and older are overweight; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: I started life as a skinny kid, and my Russian-born grandmother did her best to fatten me up, feeding me bars of cheese, cans of evaporated milk, even sticks of butter. In her day, a slender child was vulnerable to death should a serious infectious disease strike. Today, thanks to immunizations and antibiotics, we have no such excuse for rearing children with lots of pinchable inches. In fact, now the reverse -- a lean child -- is most likely to be, and remain, a healthy one.
docs.snippet: Fighting childhood obesity isn't as simple as"Don't overeat."

headline.main: The Search for the Magic Pill Audio Slide Show

docs.lead_paragraph: Stephanie Saul of The Times examines the pharmaceutical industry's search for a treatment for obesity.
docs.snippet: Stephanie Saul of The Times examines the pharmaceutical industry's search for a treatment for obesity.

docs.abstract: Editorial supports bill re-introduced by New York Assemblyman Felix Ortiz that would tax candy bars, soft drinks, supersize junk food, videos, Game Boys and anything else that contributes to alarming epidemic of obesity among children
docs.lead_paragraph: When Assemblyman Felix W. Ortiz of Brooklyn introduced his ''couch potato tax'' a few years ago, he was the darling of morning television. Mr. Ortiz, a Democrat, wanted to slap a tax on candy bars, soft drinks, supersize junk food, videos, Game Boys -- anything that is contributing to an alarming epidemic of obesity among the young. The idea drew a lot of one-liners -- some critics called Mr. Ortiz a member of the ''Twinkie police.'' But Mr. Ortiz, who keeps introducing his bill, is extremely serious. And this year he got a very important supporter: the powerful health workers' union in New York State, Local 1199.

Mr. Ortiz, a Democrat, wanted to slap a tax on candy bars, soft drinks, supersize junk food, videos, Game Boys -- anything that is contributing to an alarming epidemic of obesity among the young. The idea drew a lot of one-liners -- some critics called Mr. Ortiz a member of the ''Twinkie police.'' But Mr. Ortiz, who keeps introducing his bill, is extremely serious. And this year he got a very important supporter: the powerful health workers' union in New York State, Local 1199.
docs.snippet: Given the alarming rate of obesity among the young, the idea of taxing fattening foods deserves to evolve quickly into a real solution.
